ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Grain boundary diffusion induced reaction layer formation in Fe/Pt thin films

Affiliation.OrgName: National Technical University of Ukraine “Kiev Polytechnic Institute”

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The solid-state reaction in Pt(15 nm)/Fe(15 nm) and Pt(15 nm)/Ag(10 nm)/Fe(15 nm) thin films after post-annealing at 593 K and 613 K for different annealing times has been studied. The structural properties of these samples were investigated by various methods including depth profiling with secondary neutral mass spectrometry, transmission electron microscopy, and X-ray diffraction. It is shown that after annealing at the above temperatures where the bulk diffusion processes are still frozen, homogeneous reaction layers of FePt and FePt with about 10 at.% Ag, respectively, have been formed. Corresponding depth profiles of the element concentrations revealed strong evidence that the formation mechanism is based on a grain boundary diffusion induced solid-state reaction in which the reaction interfaces sweep perpendicularly to the original grain boundary. Interestingly, X-ray diffraction indicated that in both thin-film systems after the solid-state reaction the ordered L10 FePt phase, which is the requested phase for future magnetic data storage applications, is also present.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: It is known that at low temperatures, where bulk diffusion processes are practically frozen, even a complete intermixing of components in thin film bilayer heterostructures (binary diffusion couples) can happen by grain-boundary (GB) diffusion and GB migration through the film volume [1, 2]. Diffusion-induced grain boundary motion (DIGM) and diffusion-induced recrystallization (DIR) are the underlying processes for such kinds of GB motions. During DIR or DIGM new grains are formed with a composition different from the surrounding original grains, leading to formation of solid solutions [1] or reaction layers. Although there are still discussions in the literature about the role of chemical driving forces [3], it is more and more widely accepted that in both processes the driving forces are related to stress accumulation and relaxation ahead/around the moving boundary [1, 4, 5].

It is rather difficult to make a clear distinction experimentally between DIR and DIGM processes (see e.g. Ref. [6]). The DIR process is mainly discussed in binary systems exhibiting a wide mutual solubility range above either the miscibility gap or the critical temperature of ordering (e.g. Cu/Pd [6], Au/Cu [7], Ag/Pd [8], Ni/Cu [3, 9]). Furthermore, intermixing in nanocrystalline systems with reactive diffusion at low temperatures was investigated recently (see e.g. Refs. [10] and [11]), where different intermetallic phases were formed. As an example, in the Cu/Pd system it was observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) that the original interface between the Cu and Pd layers remained clearly visible at 473 K, but the selected area diffraction patterns in TEM indicated the presence of the PdCu phase. Furthermore, extensive intermixing had taken place after heat treatment at 533 K accompanied by grain-boundary migration, grain growth, and formation of phases (PdCu and Cu3Pd). Similar results were reported in Refs. [12] and [13], where a complete homogenization of the Pd/Cu film was observed. In this case, the bilayer structure was transformed to a homogeneous reaction layer by a peculiar grain boundary transport mechanism: instead of nucleation and formation of the reaction layer at the original interfaces, the films transform to the reaction layer by a grain boundary diffusion induced reaction (GBDIREAC) [13]. During this process there is a gradual mutual filling up of the grain boundaries of the pure films in contact followed by formation of highly alloyed regions around the GBs by interface motion perpendicular to the initial boundary.

In this work, the Pt/Fe system has been investigated in order to understand the diffusion intermixing mechanism in reactive bilayer systems at moderate temperatures. This system is of practical interest as chemically L10-ordered FePt thin films with hard magnetic properties are considered to be a very prospective material candidate for future ultra-high-density magnetic recording [14–18]. However, these films exhibit the A1 FePt disordered phase with face centred cubic structure when deposited by physical or chemical vapour deposition techniques at room temperature. Thus, high-temperature annealing is necessary to promote the A1 FePt(FCC) → L10FePt(FCT) phase transformation, but this type of heat treatment makes the fabrication process complicated. Although many efforts have been devoted to investigate in detail the fabrication of L10-ordered FePt thin films (e.g. to keep the grain-size distribution small and/or decrease the chemical ordering temperature), there are still many open questions related to the kinetics of the A1 FePt(FCC) → L10FePt(FCT) phase transformation. For instance, it has been reported that doping with a third element can enhance the chemical ordering in FePt, thus decreasing the ordering temperature for the formation of the L10 phase to relatively low process temperatures. It was found that the ordering temperature for FePt alloys with Cu doping can be drastically reduced forming a FePtCu ternary alloy [19–21], where the Fe site in the lattice was substituted by Cu. Furthermore, doping by Ag was used to reduce the ordering temperature [22–26]. However, Ag tends to chemically segregate from FePt instead of forming a ternary alloy as happened in the case of the FePt film with Cu additive and it was observed that, upon heating, the diffusion of Ag out of the FePt lattice enhanced the ordering kinetics [27, 28]. In addition, the heating rate also influences the degree of order in phases formed from Pt/Ag/Fe films, but the mechanism of the reaction layer formation still remained unclear.

In this article, we report on the kinetics of phase formation in dc magnetron sputtered Pt/Fe and Pt/Ag/Fe thin films post-annealed at 593 K and 613 K for different annealing times. The film samples were characterized by depth profiling using secondary neutral mass spectrometry (SNMS, type INA-X from SPECS GmbH, Germany) as well as TEM (JEOL 2000FX-II) and X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 using Cu K α radiation) techniques. It is worth mentioning that some illustrative, preliminary examples of the SNMS profiles from this study were already presented in our review paper [13] on GBDIREAC at 613 K for thin-film systems containing an Ag intermediate layer. In the present work these investigations are extended for films without Ag layer and for 593 K as well. Furthermore, results of TEM and XRD measurements are also presented and we give the full description of the experimental details and a thorough analysis of the experimental data.

Section2.Heading: Sample preparation and heat treatment
Section2.Para: Pt(15 nm)/Fe(15 nm) and Pt(15 nm)/Ag(10 nm)/Fe(15 nm) thin films were deposited by dc magnetron sputtering on thermally oxidized Si(100) substrates with a 100-nm-thick amorphous SiO2 layer. The base pressure of the system was 5×107 mbar, and high-purity argon of 5×103 mbar was flowed during sputtering. The nominal thickness of 15 nm for Fe and Pt layers and 10 nm for the Ag layer were evaluated from the sputtering time determined from the calibrated deposition rate of each target. The film samples were heat treated at 593 K and 613 K for different annealing times in a separate vacuum chamber (base pressure of 5×107 mbar).

Section2.Heading: SNMS depth profiling
Section2.Para:
The composition–time (depth) profiles of the samples were determined by SNMS. We used the direct bombardment mode with inductively coupled low-pressure radio-frequency Ar plasma, serving as a source for bombarding ions and also as a post-ionization medium. The Ar+ ions were directed to the sample by using a high-frequency negative bias. The sputtering area was 3 mm in diameter. In order to get good depth resolution (<2 nm) and also high intensity for concentration determination, a bias voltage of 350 V was applied to the sample. The concentration (atomic fraction in at.%) of elements was determined from the measured intensities using the linear dependence of the intensities on concentration under stationary sputter conditions [29, 30]. The time scale was converted to the depth scale to show the full concentration–depth profile only in some cases, when the sputtering rate of each layer was known (i.e. when the mixing was not too pronounced, and no reaction products were formed). The conversion was made using the sputtering rates of the different pure layers. Thus, in all of the cases, in order to help the comparison, the composition/sputtering time plots will be shown. The interfaces between the layers are not sharp in the SNMS profiles even in the case of as-deposited samples. These regions have an apparent width of about 3 nm (see depth scales in Fig. 1a and b). This width contains the combined effect of the chemical interface width (the composition change is not abrupt, but is typically about 0.5 nm with our sputtering technique), the effect of surface roughness (about 1–2 nm), and the instrumental broadening.
Fig. 1
Composition profiles of the (a) Pt(15 nm)/Fe(15 nm)/SiO2/Si and (b) Pt(15 nm)/Ag(10 nm)/Fe(15 nm)/SiO2/Si samples in the as-grown state. Corresponding depth profiles are presented next to the graphs. (Time profile in (b) is reproduced from Ref. [13], Kinetic pathways of diffusion and solid-state reactions in nanostructured thin films, Beke et al., Philosophical Magazine, 2013, reprinted by permission of Taylor & Francis Ltd., www.tandfonline.com
)

Section2.Heading: TEM and XRD investigations
Section2.Para: In order to complete the results obtained from the SNMS depth profiles, cross-sectional TEM imaging of the Pt(15 nm)/Ag(10 nm)/Fe(15 nm) sample, heat treated at 613 K for 1.5 h, was performed. Furthermore, XRD patterns, in Θ–2Θ geometry, were recorded on several heat-treated samples in order to get further structural information on the phases formed.

Section2.Heading: SNMS results on Pt/Fe bilayers
Section2.Para: Figure 1a shows the composition profile of the as-deposited Pt/Fe sample versus time (left-hand figure) and depth (right-hand figure).

After the heat treatment at 613 K for different annealing times (Fig. 2), it can be seen that at t=0.5 h and 1.0 h there is a mutual penetration of the elements into each other. The overall composition of the diffusing elements on both sides is rather high and cannot be explained by a simple filling up of grain boundaries (assuming that the GBs are completely filled by the diffusing atoms). This is because the observed values are much larger than the average value estimated from the grain size (d≅10 nm; see the TEM picture in Fig. 5). The complete filling of GBs would lead to a maximum average composition of about 5 at.% (assuming δ/d for the GB fraction, where δ=0.5 nm is the grain-boundary thickness). Furthermore, a slight asymmetry in the penetration profiles is observed: Fe penetration into the Pt layer is more intensive than Pt penetration into the Fe layer. In addition, there is a small Pt peak at the Fe/SiO2 interface due to Pt segregation (Fig. 2b).
Fig. 2
Time evolution of the composition profiles of Pt(15 nm)/Fe(15 nm)/SiO2/Si samples post-annealed at 613 K for different annealing times of (a) 0.5 h, (b) 1 h, (c) 2.5 h, and (d) 4 h

At longer annealing times (t=2.5 h and 4 h) the average compositions on both sides gradually level off and the final result is the formation of an almost homogeneous FePt layer with 50 at.%/50 at.% composition. Furthermore, there is an expressed segregation of Fe towards the free surface. The results obtained at 593 K are very similar to those obtained at 613 K revealing the same final state.

Section2.Heading: SNMS result on Pt/Ag/Fe
Section2.Para:
Figure 1b shows the composition profile of the as-deposited Pt/Ag/Fe sample versus time (left-hand figure) and depth (right-hand figure). After the heat treatment at 613 K (Fig. 3), it can be seen that (at t=0.5 h) there is an intensive intermixing between Pt and Ag, which is similar to the intermixing between Pt and Fe in the Pt/Fe sample. Furthermore, there is a definite agglomeration of Pt at the Ag/Fe interface due to Pt segregation as well as a considerable penetration of Pt into the Fe layer. In contrast, there is practically no Fe penetration into the Ag and Pt layers, and Ag shows a strong segregation towards the free surface of Pt. After 1 h of annealing, the Pt and Ag layers are strongly intermixed and at the same time there is an increased penetration of Pt into the Fe layer as well as Pt agglomeration at the Fe/SiO2 interface due to Pt segregation. At longer annealing times (t=1.5 h, 3.25 h, and 4 h) the compositions of all the three elements gradually level off and the final state is the formation of an almost homogeneous reaction layer with Ag at the free surface. In addition, at intermediate annealing times (t=1.5 h and 3.25 h) there is some indication that a PtAg phase has been formed.
Fig. 3
Time evolution of the composition profiles of Pt(15 nm)/Ag(10 nm)/Fe(15 nm)/SiO2/Si samples post-annealed at 613 K for different annealing times of (a) 0.5 h, (b) 1 h, (c) 1.5, (d) 3.25 h, and (e) 4 h. (Note that this figure differs from the similar figure in Ref. [13] due to corrections in background handling)

The results obtained at 593 K are qualitatively similar to those obtained at 613 K. However, since at this lower temperature the processes are slower, some details are more clearly seen for shorter annealing times. Figure 4 shows the composition profiles obtained after 1 h and 4 h annealing at 593 K, revealing the gradual intermixing of Pt and Ag, and the segregation of Ag on the free surface of Pt and at the Fe/SiO2 interface, respectively. Furthermore, the slower penetration of Pt into Fe layer is also observed.
Fig. 4
Composition profiles of the Pt(15 nm)/Ag(10 nm)/Fe(15 nm)/SiO2/Si samples post-annealed at 593 K for (a) 1 h and (b) 4 h

Section2.Heading: TEM and XRD results
Section2.Para:
TEM images taken on the Pt/Ag/Fe sample annealed at 613 K for 1.5 h are shown in Fig. 5. In accordance with Fig. 3c, the following conclusions can be drawn: (i) the lower part of the sample (bordered by the free surface and interface A in Fig. 5a) consists of two regions, which reveal a slightly different contrast in brightness; both seem to be not fully homogeneous but (at least in some parts) are surrounded by a still sharp contrast and consist of a mixture of two different areas. This part corresponds to a 15 nm wide region with different average compositions of Pt and Ag (see Fig. 3c up to about 18 s sputtering time), inside which the Ag segregation at the free surface is followed by an intermixed Ag–Pt layer. (ii) In the remaining upper part of the sample the original interface between the deposited Ag and Fe layers is still well recognizable as marked in Fig. 5b (interface B), which corresponds to the position at about 30 s in Fig. 3c. Around this interface, there are small grains (of about 5 nm in size) surrounded by larger grains in the region closer to the original Ag/Fe interface (see bright areas in Fig. 5b near to interface B). Note that, because of the inhomogeneity of the (grain) structure of the sample in Fig. 5, two micrographs from two different parts of the same specimen are shown illustrating some differences in the morphology developed.
Fig. 5
TEM images of two different parts of the Pt(15 nm)/Ag(10 nm)/Fe(15 nm)/SiO2/Si sample which was post-annealed at 613 K for 1.5 h. In (b) some GBs (perpendicular as well as non-perpendicular to the interface) are also pointed out by arrows

The XRD pattern of the Fe/Pt sample annealed for 4 h at 613 K is presented in Fig. 6. The reflection at 48.7∘ clearly originates from L10 FePt(002) grains. Reflections at 41.1∘ and 47.6∘ can originate from both the A1 and the L10 phases, since the two structures have very close peaks here: 40.98∘ (111) and 47.66∘ (200) for the A1 phase and 41.08∘ (111) and 47.16∘ (200) for the L10 phase. There are no peaks corresponding to reflections from pure Fe and Pt. Please note that the strong and sharp reflection at 32.9∘ belongs to the Si(002) substrate (this peak is frequently observed in deformed substrates), which might overlap a weaker FePt(110) reflection (shoulder on the left-hand side of the reflection). Based on these results, one can conclude that at least a considerable portion of the sample has been transformed to the ordered L10 phase.
Fig. 6
XRD Θ–2Θ pattern of the Pt(15 nm)/Fe(15 nm)/SiO2/Si sample post-annealed for 4 h at 613 K. The smoothed scan is shown with a bold line (blue online) for convenience, whereas the raw scan can be seen in grey

The XRD patterns of the Fe/Ag/Pt films annealed for 1 and 4 h at 613 K are shown in Fig. 7a and b, respectively. After 1 h of annealing two marked peaks at 39.8∘ and 46.4∘ are observed originating from Pt(111) and Pt(200) reflections. Furthermore, weak peaks at 38.2∘ and 44.4∘ are visible, which correspond to Ag(111) and Ag(200), respectively. This is in agreement with SNMS data (Fig. 3b), indicating that pure Pt and Ag layers are still present after annealing. Significant changes can be seen after 4 h of annealing (Fig. 7b), where the Pt peaks vanished and an additional peak appeared at around 41∘. At this angle the FePt A1 and L10 structures have very similar peak positions (the difference is about 0.1∘, see above). The same applies for the additional peak appearing at 47.5∘. Low-intensity peaks are also visible at around 33∘ and 49∘, which could correspond to the L10 phase. The peak at 38.2∘ clearly indicates the presence of Ag. These results suggest that the Fe/Ag/Pt layer stack finally transformed into a mixture of a FePt alloy (part of which is also ordered) and an Ag phase.
Fig. 7
XRD Θ–2Θ patterns of the Pt(15 nm)/Ag(10 nm)/Fe(15 nm)/SiO2/Si sample post-annealed at 613 K for (a) 1 h and (b) 4 h. The smoothed scan is shown with a bold line (blue online) for convenience, whereas the raw scan can be seen in grey

It is worth noting that a detailed analysis about the presence of about 10 % Ag (as indicated by the SNMS spectra in Fig. 3e) in the FePt phase and especially about the positions of the Ag atoms is not possible from these data alone. Furthermore, again due to the small size of our samples, we were not able to identify reflections from the Ag–Pt phase as suggested by the SNMS depth profiles and it was difficult to get a more quantitative conclusion about the ratio of the ordered and disordered phases formed.

Section1.Heading: Discussion
Section1.Para: The results presented above indicate a special way of nucleation and growth of homogeneous (ordered or disordered) reaction products in these thin-film systems. First of all, it can be concluded that all the changes observed should be the result of grain boundary/interface mass transport. Considering that the diffusion coefficient of Fe in Pt is about 2×10−27 m2/s and of Pt in Fe is about 4×10−30 m2/s at 600 K, this leads to diffusion lengths of 5×10−12 m and 2×10−13 m, respectively; thus, at such low temperatures, the bulk diffusion lengths are negligible [31].

Section2.Heading: Pt/Fe bilayer system
Section2.Para: In this system grain-boundary diffusion of Pt into the Fe layer and Fe into the Pt layer takes place (Fig. 2). Thus, in the first stage of the process the GBs of both initial layers gradually fill up with the other element and after arriving at the other interface they even segregate at these surfaces of arrival. Indeed, there is a strong segregation of Fe at the free surface and (a more moderate) segregation of Pt to the Fe/Si interface (see Fig. 2a and b). It was shown recently that this process can be well characterized by a bimodal GB network with different (fast and low) diffusivities [12, 13, 32, 33]. The fast-diffusivity boundaries were saturated in the first stage of the process, and segregation took place at the interface(s). These segregated layers serve as back-diffusion sources and further diffusion took place along the low-diffusivity boundaries.

However, as was already estimated, the large average amount of Fe (Pt) inside the Pt (Fe) layer cannot be explained by the simple saturation of the GBs with the diffusing element. The observed phenomenon can be explained by a process similar to DIR and DIGM [1, 2]. In both cases, grain-boundary diffusion initiates the nucleation of the reaction product and the sweep of the GBs perpendicular to their original surfaces and as a result an alloyed zone remains behind the moving GB. The composition of this alloyed zone can depend on many factors (see e.g. the recent paper by Schmitz et al. [1]), but in the case of binary systems with a tendency to form intermetallic compounds, the region behind can correspond to such a phase. In this case, as compared to DIR in ideal systems [1], having complete mutual solubility, where the stress accumulation and relaxation play the determining role, even chemical driving forces have to be considered for the full understanding of the details of these processes.

Indeed, with increasing annealing time the reaction layers formed around the GBs can become larger and larger (increasing the average composition obtained by the depth profiling in Fig. 2c and d) and, finally, after the consumption of the pure matrices, the final result is a homogeneous FePt phase. Thus, by this grain boundary diffusion induced reaction layer formation, GBDIREAC [13], the details of the observed phenomena can be qualitatively understood. Furthermore, according to the XRD results shown in Fig. 6, this phase is partially ordered. The formation of such an ordered phase might be surprising at first sight. In this regard, in the usual technological fabrication processes using sputter deposition the A1 phase forms first and only from this phase does the nucleation and growth of the ordered L10 phase take place at high temperatures. However, in our case the intermixing takes place by GB/interface diffusion and thermal migration of atoms, which is an easy path for phase formation at reduced temperatures.

Section2.Heading: Pt/Ag/Fe film system
Section2.Para: Let us now consider the role of the intermediate Ag layer. In the interpretation obviously one has to take into account the fact that in the Pt/Ag system different intermetallic compounds exist, but in the Ag/Fe system the components are practically insoluble.

It can be seen in Fig. 4a and b that at the beginning there is a very similar intermixing between the Pt and Ag layers compared to the intermixing between the Pt and Fe layers observed in the Pt/Fe films. Thus, the GBs in both films are gradually filled up and there is Ag segregation at the surface and Pt segregation at the Ag/Fe interface. It is worth mentioning that, according to the difference of melting points, it is expected that the diffusion of Pt into the Ag GBs must be faster than the diffusion of Ag into the Pt GBs. It can be seen in Fig. 4a that it is indeed the case at the beginning (note the more intensive penetration of Pt into the Ag layer compared to Ag into Pt as illustrated by the higher Pt content in the Ag layer). However, at longer annealing times, because of the stronger segregation of Ag to the free surface as compared to the segregation of Pt at the Ag/Fe interface, the stronger back source of Ag can lead to a more expressed increase of the overall Ag content in the Pt layer as compared to the overall Pt content in the Ag layer. There is a similar explanation for the higher average composition of Fe in Pt as compared to the average Pt content in Fe in the case of Pt/Fe layers (see Fig. 2a).

After 1.5 and 4 h of annealing, a more expressed diffusion of Pt into the Fe layer is observed (Fig. 3). At the same time, in accordance with the very restricted solid solubilities, there is practically no penetration of Fe and Ag along Ag and Fe GBs, respectively. At longer annealing times, the reaction layer formation (presumably Ag–Pt) around the Pt and Ag GBs becomes more and more intensive and the area of these reacted parts becomes comparable with the unreacted parts. This can be seen from Fig. 3b and c and in the TEM picture (Fig. 5a), where the Pt layer consists of dark, unreacted Pt grains and white reaction layers around the GBs. Unfortunately, we were not able to detect reflections from the Ag–Pt phase by XRD.

Furthermore, there is also a Pt/Fe reaction layer formation around the GBs of Fe. In this case interestingly the average composition profile is not flat but has a relatively high slope in the first part of the Fe layer (see e.g. Fig. 3 at 1.5 h). This can indicate the effect of the grain-boundary morphology: if there are GBs not only perpendicular to the interface (bamboo structure), but also parallel to it, the reaction layer formation can also take place inside the layer, parallel to the initial interface (see Fig. 5b, where GBs not only perpendicular but also parallel to the substrate plane are visible). Finally, at similar annealing times as observed in the Pt/Fe system, a complete homogenization can be observed (Fig. 3d and e), i.e. the Fe gradually penetrates into the almost reacted Pt/Ag area, resulting in the gradual dissolution of the Ag–Pt phase, and at the same time the consumption of the remaining Fe grains by the Fe/Pt reaction layers also takes place. The final state is a homogenous FePt phase with about 10 at.% Ag, and an Ag top layer due to strong segregation to the free surface. The presence of this phase was also confirmed by XRD as shown in Fig. 7 at t=4 h. Furthermore, the pronounced segregation of Ag to the free surface of FePt is in accordance to first-principles calculations [34].

Our results suggest that the formed FePt and FePt(Ag) phases are partially ordered, which is somehow surprising. Doping of FePt films with Ag is well known to reduce the ordering temperature by enhancing the ordering kinetics, which is induced by diffusing out from the FePt lattice. In our low-temperature case the situation is different. Here, in the Pt(15 nm)/Ag(10 nm)/Fe(15 nm) film the Ag–Pt phase forms first and only after this the intermixing becomes more intensive between the Pt (and Ag) and Fe layers. Similarly, in the Pt(15 nm)/Fe(15 nm) film the intermixing along GBs can enhance the nucleation and growth of the ordered phase.

Furthermore, in order to illustrate the effect of the initial state (GB size and distribution) on the phase-formation process, the same heat treatment was applied to a different sample but of the same sample batch. Figure 8 shows the corresponding SNMS profile obtained at the same temperature and annealing time (613 K and 4 h) as for the sample shown in Fig. 3e. It can be seen that the time at which the final homogenization is established is quite different. This can be the effect of slight differences in the GB structure (either in the grain size or in the grain-boundary morphology). This behaviour was also observed in Ag/Pd systems, which revealed a similar GB diffusion controlled homogenization processes [2].
Fig. 8
Composition profile of a different Pt(15 nm)/Ag(10 nm)/Fe(15 nm)/SiO2/Si sample, which was post-annealed at 613 K for 4 h. A clear difference compared to Fig. 3e is apparent. (Figure is reproduced from Ref. [13], Kinetic pathways of diffusion and solid-state reactions in nanostructured thin films, Beke et al., Philosophical Magazine, 2013, reprinted by permission of Taylor & Francis Ltd., www.tandfonline.com
)

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: We have shown by the combination of SNMS depth profiling and TEM and XRD investigations that low-temperature annealing of Pt/Fe and Pt/Ag/Fe thin films led to the formation of completely homogeneous reaction layers of FePt and FePt with about 10 at.% Ag, respectively. The underlying formation processes, observed from the SNMS depth profiles, are interpreted by grain boundary diffusion induced GB migration perpendicular to the original GB plane during which the compound layers are formed. This GBDIREAC mechanism was supported by TEM imaging and XRD analysis. The latter indicated that in both thin-film systems the ordered L10 FePt phase has been formed, which is considered to be a very prospective material candidate for future ultra-high-density magnetic recording.
